assign_distances(graph, scaling_factor=1.0)¶

This method is for assigning distances from the kernel density estimation of the NSF net

Parameters

  • scaling_factor –

  • graph – graph to be assigned distances

  • scaling_factor – factor by which to scale distances by: avg_link_dist/1463

Returns

graph

Return type

nx.Graph()

assign_distances_grid(graph, pythagorus=False, harvesine=False, lon='y', lat='x')¶

This method assigns the distances of a graph using a grid system. :param graph: graph to assign distances :param pythagorus: if set to true, it calculates distances purely from pythagorus :param harvesine: if set to true, it calculates distances accordingly using harvesine formula :param lon: node attribute name for longitude - default “y” - only applies to harvesine calculation :param lat: node attribute name for lattitude - default “x” - only applies to harvesine calculation :return: graph with distances assigned

choice_prob(alpha=None, beta=None, BA_pure=False, log_distance=False, waxman_graph=False, SBAG=False, normalise=True, BA_plus_dist=False)¶

Method to create a destination node probability list given the source node and the graph on which to perform this.

Parameters

  • N_S – Source node for which the probability list is meant for.

  • graph – Graph for which to create the probability list from (needs x and y coordinate (longitude and lattitude))

Returns

list of probabilites corresponding to the choice of nodes

create_BA_ACMN(N, k, collection_name=None, database_name=None)¶

Method to create a Barabási and Albert based random graph, which works on the principle of “rich get richer” :param N: The number of nodes in the graph :param k: mean k to create the graphs with (avg_degree) :param collection_name: collection name under which to make the check for uniqueness :param database_name: Name of database to save in. :return: graph (nx graph)

create_ER_ACMN(N, p, collection_name=None, database_name=None)¶

Method to create Erdoes-Renyi graphs with checks for minimal topological charachteristiscs for OPtical Networks. :param N: The number of nodes in the graph :param p: the probability of having a link added (N*p = avg_degree) :param collection_name: collection name under which to make the check for uniqueness :param database_name: Name of database to save in. :return: graph (nx graph)

create_WS_ACMN(N, k, p, collection_name=None, database_name=None)¶

Method to create Watts-Strogatz graph that returns a Watts strogatz graph, with minimal topological parameters for optical networks. :param N: Number of nodes in the graph :param k: mean k to create the graphs with (avg_degree) :param p: possibility of making a connection :param collection_name: collection name under which to make the check for uniqueness :param database_name: database name under which to make the check for uniqueness :return: graph (nx graph)

create_binary_topology_vector(graph)¶
Parameters

graph –

Returns

create_random_ACMN(N, alpha, collection_name=None, database_name=None)¶

This method creates a randomly generated graph that is subject to constraints C1, C2 and unique topology within the _topology_vectors.csv file. It return a graph and topology vector for said graph.

Parameters

  • N – Number of Nodes

  • L – Number of Links

  • alpha – Connectivity of graph

Returns

graph, topology_vector

Return type

nx.Graph()

create_random_ACMN_dataset(N, amount, database_name, collection_name, use_dask=True, BA=False, WS=False, ER=False, random=False, pref_grid=False, alpha=None, k=None, p=None, grid_graph=None, L=None, bar=None)¶

This method is used to create ACMN datasets, which creates the specified amount of topologies randomly, with the specified amount of distance realisations.

Parameters

  • N – Number of nodes of ACMN

  • L – Number of links of ACMN

  • alpha – Connectivity of graph

  • amount – Amount of ACMN networks to create

  • distance_realisations – Amount of network distance realisations to create

Returns

None, saves all topologies to disk in Optical-Networks ->Topology

Return type

None

create_random_ACMN_grid(N, L, pos, collection_name=None, database_name=None, degree_max=5, scaling_factor=1.0, pythagorus=False, harvesine=False, weighted=False)¶

Method to create random ACMN with a pre-determined grid structure. :param N: Number of node :param L: Number of links :param pos: list of tuples with x and y pos :param collection_name: database collection name :param database_name: database name :param degree_max: max degree allowed :return: ACMN - nx.Graph()

create_real_based_grid_graph(grid_graph, L, choice_prob_func=None, degree_max=5, degree_min=2, database_name=None, collection_name=None, alternating_pref_random=False)¶

Method to create graphs that are based on real node locations, however are randomly connected in a fashion that mimics real network topologies. Weighting probabilites either by degree or distances between nodes. :param grid_graph: graph from real topology :param L: Number of links to insert into graph :param degree_max: maximum degree to allow :param degree_min: minimum degree to allow :return: ACMN - nx.Graph()

create_save_database_ACMN(N, collection_name, database_name, grid_graph=None, L=None, BA=False, ER=False, WS=False, random=False, pref_grid=False, alpha=None, k=None, p=None, node_data=False)¶

Method to create one of the random graph structures and save it to a database connected to. :param N: Number of nodes :param collection_name: collection name to save the graph under :param database_name: database name under which to save the graph :param BA: Set to True for Barabase-Alvert Graph :param ER: Set to True for Erdoes-Renyi Graph :param WS: Set to True for Watts-Strogatz :param random: Set to True for random uniform :param alpha: connectivity if creating random uniform graph :param k: mean degree k for WS, BA :param p: parameter p for ER, WS :return: None

NetworkSimulator¶

class NetworkToolkit.NetworkSimulator.NetworkSimulator¶
incremental_uniform_demand_simulation(graph, routing_func='FF-kSP', channel_bandwidth=32000000000.0, start_bandwidth=0, incremental_bandwidth=1000000000.0, e=0)¶

Method to simulate incremental uniform demand routing simulations.

Parameters

  • graph – Graph to use for optical network simulation - nx.Graph()

  • channels – Amount of channels in ON - int

  • channel_bandwidth – Channel bandwidth - float

  • start_bandwidth – Start Demand bandwidth - float

  • incremental_bandwidth – Bandwidth to increment with each step - float

Returns

Dictionary with simulation results

Return type

dictionary

incremental_uniform_demand_simulation_graph_list(graph_list, routing_func='FF-kSP', channel_bandwidth=32000000000.0, start_bandwidth=0, incremental_bandwidth=1000000000.0, e=0)¶

Method to feed in graph_list and automate the incremental uniform demand simulations.

Parameters

  • graph_list – List of graphs gotten from database - list

  • routing_func – Function to use for routing,

check Network.py for details - string string :param channel_bandwidth: Bandwidth of channels - float :param start_bandwidth: Initial demand bandwidth to start with - float :param incremental_bandwidth: Bandwidth to increment with - float :param e: Maximum MNH+e length paths to allow in k-SP

Optical Network Tools¶

class NetworkToolkit.Network.OpticalNetwork(graph, B_o=5000000000000.0, channel_bandwidth=32000000000.0, mimic_topology='nsf', routing_func='FF-kSP')¶
convert_bandwidth_to_connection(bandwidth_demand, SNR_matrix)¶

Method to convert bandwidth demands into WDM fixed grid connection requests with SNR worst case estimation.

Parameters

bandwidth_demand – TM with banwidth demands

Returns

TM with connection requests

create_dynamic_demand(n_t, min_bandwidth, max_bandwidth, _lambda, _mu)¶

Method to create a set of demand matrices with poisson process generated bandwidth demands, given a normalised demand distribution over nodes. It then uses worst case SNR esetimation to tell us how many connections of given bandwidth to setup and return the demand matrices in terms of their connection request demands.

Parameters

  • n_t – The amount of connections to establish (amount of traffic)

  • min_bandwidth – min bandwdth demands (Gbps)

  • max_bandwidth – max bandwidth demands (Gbps)

  • _lambda – distribution mean for exponentional distribution to use to generate the time between connetions to be established

  • _mu – distrinution mean for exponentional distribution to use to generate the time between establishing connections and tearing them down.

Returns

array of demand matrices for connection requests shape - (2*n_t, nodes, nodes)

estimate_worst_case_SNR()¶

Method that estimates the worst case SNR for each node pair with estimating full occupancy.

Returns

SNR_list - (s, d, SNR)

get_SNR_matrix()¶

Demand Tools¶

class NetworkToolkit.Demand.Demand(graph)¶
construct_poisson_process_demand_matrix(demand_data)¶

Method to construct a demand matrix for poisson process demand (dynamic) time based.

Parameters

demand_data – dict of demand data - {“id”:id, “sn”:source node, “dn”:destination node, “bandwidth”:bandwidth requirement for connections, “time”: time, “establish”:establish - 1 takedown -0, “index”:index}

Returns

list of demand matrices

create_poisson_process_demand(n_t, min_bandwidth, max_bandwidth, _lambda, _mu, demand_distribution=array([], dtype=float64))¶

Method to create poisson demand scheme for dynamic demand for time series analysis.

Parameters

  • n_t – number of traffic

  • min_bandwidth – minimum bandwidth demand

  • max_bandwidth – maximum bandwidth demand

  • _lambda – mean for exponential distribution of start times

  • _mu – mean for exponential distribution of end times of connections

:param demand_distribution:the normalised distribution over nodes :return: dict of demand data - {“id”:id, “sn”:source node, “dn”:destination node, “bandwidth”:bandwidth requirement for connections,

“time”: time, “establish”:establish - 1 takedown -0, “index”:index}

Parameters

bandwidth – uniform bandwidth between each node pair

Returns

demand matrix

create_uniform_connection_requests(set)¶

Method to create a uniform connections requests matrix.

Returns

demand matrix

get_SPM_n(COI, gamma, bandwidth, alpha, D)¶

This method calculates the self phase modulation (SPM) noise coefficient for a given channel of interest(COI)

Parameters

  • frequency_i – frequency of COI

  • gamma – non-linear-coefficient

  • bandwidth – bandwidth of channel (32Gbaud channels - same bandwidth)

  • C_r – slope of the linear regression of the normalized Raman gain spectrum

  • alpha – attenuation coefficient

  • beta_2 – GVD parameter

  • beta_3 – slope of GVD parameter

Returns

SPM coefficient

“:rtype: float

get_XPM_n(COI, edge, gamma, bandwidth, alpha, D)¶

This method calculates the cross phase modulation (XPM) for a given COI and edge in a graph with other interfering channels. It does it for variably loaded channels.

Parameters

  • COI – Channel of interest (integer - corresponds to the wavelengths used for channel)

  • edge – Link of graph that is being calculated for

  • graph – graph that is being considered (nx.Graph())

  • gamma – non-linear-coefficient

  • bandwidth – bandwidth of channel (32Gbaud channels - same bandwidth)

  • C_r – slope of the linear regression of the normalized Raman gain spectrum

  • alpha – attenuation coefficient

  • launch_power – power at which channel is launched (dBm)

  • beta_2 – GVD parameter

  • beta_3 – slope of GVD parameter

Returns

XPM coefficient

Return type

float

  • alpha_n –

  • bandwidth_WDM –

get_non_linear_coefficient(edge, gamma=0.0012, bandwidth=32000000000, alpha=4.605111673958094e-05, D=1.6999999999999996e-05, coherence_factor=0, Plot=False, name='ISRS', channels_full=156)¶

This method calculates the SPM and XPM coefficients and returns the total non-linear coefficient.

Parameters

  • D – Dispersion parameter

  • spans – amount of spans the link has

  • COI – Channel of interest (integer - corresponds to the wavelengths used for channel)

  • edge – Link of graph that is being calculated for

  • graph – graph that is being considered (nx.Graph())

  • gamma – non-linear-coefficient

  • bandwidth – bandwidth of channel (32Gbaud channels - same bandwidth)

  • C_r – slope of the linear regression of the normalized Raman gain spectrum

  • alpha – attenuation coefficient

  • beta_2 – GVD parameter

  • beta_3 – slope of GVD parameter

  • coherence_factor – (…)

Returns

non-linear coefficient

Return type

float

Routing Tools¶

class NetworkToolkit.Routing.Heuristics.Heuristics(graph, channels, channel_bandwidth)¶
FF_WA(graph, LA, channels, channel_bandwidth)¶

Method to assign wavelengths for all paths previously assigned. :param graph: Graph to use - nx.Graph() :param LA: Lightpath assignment - list :param channels: Amount of channels available - int :param channel_bandwidth: Channel bandwidth available - float :return: Wavelength assignment dictionary - dict

FF_kSP(traffic_matrix_connection_requests, e=0, order_aware=False, sort_length=False)¶

This method implements a first fit k shortest paths algorithm for a optical transport network. Call a k-shortest path method before calling this method. :return: None - assigns light paths and wavelengths to global variables that can then be accessed. :rtype: None

FF_return(graph, channels, W, path)¶

Method to return the first available wavelength for a path W: ExChannes matrix and a path. :param graph: Graph to use - nx.Graph() :param channels: Amount of Channels to use - int :param W: Exchange matrix - ndarray :param path: Path to find wavelength for - list :return: Wavelength for path - int

add_wavelength_path_to_W(graph, W, path, wavelength)¶

Method to add a wavelength to a W matrix :param graph: Graph to use - nx.Graph() :param W: W matrix to add to - ndarray :param path: Path to add the wavelength to - list :param wavelength: Wavelength to add to - int :return: The new W matrix - ndarray

kSP_CA_LA(graph, k_SP, traffic_matrix_connection_requests)¶

This method assigns the lightpaths for MNH weighting and congestion awareness. :param graph: Graph to use - nx.Graph() :param k_SP: List of k shortest paths - list :param traffic_matrix_connection_requests: NxN numpy array that gives the connection requests for the scheme to assign. - nparray :return: List of light paths - list

k_SP_CA_FF(traffic_matrix_connection_requests, e=0)¶

Method to do the lightpath assignment with k-shortest-paths congestion-aware and the wavelength assignment with first fit. :param traffic_matrix_connection_requests: The number NxN array that holds the traffic connection requests. :return: None

k_SP_FF(traffic_matrix_connection_requests, e=0)¶

Method that implements the k shortest path first fit algorithm for RWA. :param traffic_matrix_connection_requests: NxN matrix of connections to be established :param e: k+e length paths to be used :return: whether the TM was blocked or not - Boolean

k_SP_LA(graph, k_SP, traffic_matrix_connection_requests)¶

Method for the lightpath assignment after the k-shortest path scheme. :param graph: Graph to use - nx.Graph() :param k_SP: list of k-shortest paths - list returned from Tools.get_k_shortest_paths_MNH(graph, e=e) :param traffic_matrix_connection_requests: NxN numpy array that gives the connection requests for the scheme to assign. - nparray :return: Lightpaths - list

static_baroni_simple_SNR_LA(graph, k_SP, iter=100000, initial_demand=True)¶

Deprecated - update This method assigns lightpaths given SNR weighting and also congestion awareness. :param initial_demand: :param iter: limit for the iteration of to try and ease the congestion on highly congested links :return: None

static_optimised_baroni_MNH_LA(graph, k_SP, e=5)¶

This method implements the optimised baroni MNH lightpath assignment. Call k-shortest path algorithm before for the self.equal_cost_path variable to be available. It will assign a lightpath assignment to a single uniform demand between every node pair in the graph. :param graph: Graph to use - nx.Graph() :param k_SP: List of k-shortest paths - list :param e: Len(MNH) + e to allow for finding new k-shortest paths - int :return: List of lightpaths - list :rtype: list

class NetworkToolkit.Routing.ILP.ILP(graph, channels, channel_bandwidth)¶
maximise_throughput()¶
maximise_uniform_set_demands()¶
minimise_wavelengths()¶
static_ILP(max_seconds=600, min_wave=False, max_D=False, solver_name='GRB')¶

This method implements a static ILP solution for the k-shortest equal cost paths in a optical transport network. Make sure to call k-shortest paths (MNH or SNR) to get the k-shortest paths before calling this method. :return: Nothing, assigns a global RWA to wavelengths and lightpaths variables. :rtype: None
